title: 110_hr4308
content: The Act titled "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007" includes a section on the short title and another section on the establishment of the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. The Fund can be used for advertising purposes, limited to 10% of the transferred amounts each fiscal year, not exceeding $1,000,000. The National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 allows the Administrator to use up to $200,000 annually for administering prize competitions. Any remaining funds can be used for prizes awarded under the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing excess funds in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury can acquire obligations on original issue or by purchase, and sell them at market price. Interest and proceeds from the sale of obligations held in the Fund will be credited to the Fund. NASA INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise the Administrator on the program authorized under this section and section 4. The Advisory Committee consists of 5 U.S. citizens with expertise in mathematics or science education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The Committee includes individuals from academia, the nonprofit sector, and the private sector, with a Chair and Vice Chair appointed by the Administrator. The Advisory Committee for the NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship consists of 5 members appointed by the Administrator with expertise in mathematics or science education. Each member serves a three-year term, with staggered initial terms for continuity. Vacancies are filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term, and members may not serve consecutive terms. The Advisory Committee for the NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship consists of 5 members appointed by the Administrator with expertise in mathematics or science education. Each member serves a three-year term, with staggered initial terms for continuity. Vacancies are filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term, and members may not serve consecutive terms. The Committee appointed under paragraph (1) may not serve on the Advisory Committee for more than 6 years. No compensation is paid to members, but they are reimbursed for expenses. The Advisory Committee must meet at least 4 times a year, with the Administrator and Chief of Strategic Communications of NASA present at each meeting. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A person approved for the program is known as a "sponsor". The logo will include the words "NASA Innovation Fund Partner". The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allows individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. Applicants must submit a proposal including the amount to be contributed and a description of their promotional program related to science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The Advisory Committee reviews the proposals and makes recommendations to the Administrator. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allows individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. Approved applicants must enter into a sponsorship agreement with the Administrator, providing a specified amount and promoting educational programs and opportunities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allows individuals to use the Partnership Logo in their promotional program, subject to restrictions such as no logos on spacecraft, no astronaut endorsements, no agency-wide endorsements, and no in-kind contributions. The Administrator establishes procedures to protect proprietary information submitted. Congress encourages NASA to participate in activities authorized in subsection (c) of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958 and provide assistance to sponsors for promotional programs as deemed appropriate. The Administrator may take legal action against unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo in promotions, with a penalty of $100,000 per violation. Sponsors implementing unauthorized promotional programs using the logo may also face consequences. The Administrator can take legal action against unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo in promotions, with penalties of $100,000 per violation. A report must be submitted to Congress annually, detailing actions taken by NASA, receipts, expenditures, and an evaluation of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Advisory Committee must submit a report to Congress annually on its actions, and consult with various NASA Centers for program improvement ideas. SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENT. Amends section 314(i) of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Defines key terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
